What have they been doing this whole time?NASA are not using 50 year old technology in the Artemis program, that would be silly. They’re using 30, 35 year old tech at best in the form of the SLS. Although their avionics and control systems will be state of the art, the basic vehicle structure and engine design are really just a derivative of the STS (Space Shuttle) developed in the early 80s.Look familiar? They should, pretty much everything is a hand me down from the Space Shuttle program, right up to using actual spare RS-25 Shuttle main engines that were flown on a Shuttle.Now it may seem bizarre doing this, but there are good reasons for doing so. The Space Shuttle main engines still hold the record for the best specific impulse (Isp) of any chemical engine ever flown, giving them the highest possible efficiency for the job. The solid fuel boosters (SRBs) that mount on either side offer huge thrust and are easy to build (admittedly at the cost of poor efficiency), and the best bit is that it’s all well established technology that has been in use for several decades under the STS program, and has a mature manufacturing base behind it.On the surface it sounds like the perfect way to build a kick arse system very cheaply and reliably, since everything is well understood and established. Congress loved the idea since it keeps aerospace factories manned up and working in key states, and a happy workforce are votes in the hand. The only fly in the ointment is the rather uncomfortable fact that Boeing (the actual company building the vehicle) seems to require around two billion dollars for the first example, which is inexplicably several years behind schedule. So far NASA has spent the best part of $9 billion on this system without a single flight as of yet.Another uncomfortable fact is that there is nothing reusable about the SLS. The beautiful RS-25 main engines that were reflown with every Shuttle flight will be expended on the SLS, hell, even the SRBs will not be recovered in this new application, unlike the old STS ones which were.Basically, what we have here is a Space Shuttle without the orbiter, which gives it a huge lift capacity (95 tonnes to LEO to start with), but at the same high cost as the Space Shuttle with none of the reusability. Flight cadence will be restricted to how fast Boeing can construct them, which doesn’t fill people with confidence considering how far behind they have run so far. At the moment the SLS really looks like a “jobs for the boys” project, authorised by a cynical Congress in order to retain their seats.NASA are quite happy to run with the system since it allows them to shoot for the moon again, and gives them something to launch their own baby, the Orion Crew Capsule. NASA has been been working on and developing this with Lockheed Martin for the last 14 years at an eye watering cost of $18.7 billion, and the vehicle is envisioned as a true deep space craft that could be used for interplanetary work.Right now, NASA is committed to project Artemis, and as of right now, the only way to get the Orion into cislunar space is with the SLS (which we are assured by Boeing will be ready…… um soon,A combination of both the SpaceX Falcon Heavy and ULA Vulcan systems would require more launches, but would save NASA billions.
